ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: principles of roman law, roman history, how to evaluate legal systems and how the law effects society
I learned quite a bit of technical information about the legal system of ancient Rome -- laws concerning marriage, delict, inheritance, contract, slavery, and more.

So much!! About the Roman legal system, Roman history, how to write cases, how to study cases - since Prof Lenski structures the class like an actual 6th-century law class for a law student in Beirut, it's really something very different from any other history class you'll take at Yale.
Roman law and the history of roman jurisprudence
I learned a lot about Roman legal concepts in the context of Roman history -- it was truly an eye-opening experience!
Developed a nuanced understand of both Roman culture and society as well as the laws )and historical context of those laws) that governed them

I developed greater knowledge of ancient Roman society and law, including the events that inspired certain provisions and sociological reasons for its language. You really get a sense of how to Romans thought and why their legal system persisted into the modern era as a foundation for international law. Since it is a law class, you focus a lot on specific cases and solving case studies using the legal code, so you will gain skills in applying the law, forming arguments, and defending your interpretations.
Everything Roman Law!
I learned how Roman Law functioned and evolved all the way into modern common law and some parts of U.S. law.
This was a really nice introduction to the different areas of Roman law, how to structure arguments, and a decent amount of history as well.
Roman legal history and how to apply it to cases
Ability to debate using legislation and cultural tendencies from Roman republic and empire.
I gained an overall understanding of law

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
strengths: really informative lectures, great relations to modern day, fun case study sections, super organized class
weaknesses: some of the secondary source readings were ehhh

Strengths: Structured like a "real" law class, fair amount of work, engaging subject matter

Weaknesses: Tough exams that are challenging to prep for, lots of memorization and little analysis required for success

This is an absolutely amazing class! I can't think of any shortcomings. It's informative, well-structured, and the assignments are fun and not repetitive. I wish there were more chances of getting to know Prof Lenski, because he seems a very cool person too!

Strengths: Prof. Lenski was a fantastic lecturer, and the course material was extremely well-organized. Weakness: almost none, except that it was a lot of memorization (which is not necessarily a weakness because committing things to memory helped me better grasp the concepts covered in class)
The course is highly detailed and there were really strong sources that served as a consistent reference and complement to class material

STRENGTH: Content is structured well in a way that facilitates student learning, sections are designed such that there is a lot of student engagement and they don't feel like a waste of time where you just regurgitate readings, the trips to the international law library at YLS and coin/papyri collections are really interesting and serve to bring the material to life, the workload is super manageable and feedback is clear.

WEAKNESS: N/A
It was a great course, I cannot think of any improvemnets.
I really enjoyed the opportunities to apply the knowledge from lectures to section discussions.
I really enjoyed sections, I think class could incorporate more history and more applications
The material is specific and meticulous. The lectures are repetitive.

Strength: if you like Roman Law, this is a great class with you. Professor is very knowledgable

Weakness: lots and lots of information that can feel drastically overwhelming especially at final times

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: This is a great class if you're interested in law or history. Prof. Lenski does a great job of balancing the two elements in his instruction. You really need to read the textbook and it's a very dense read. However, the lectures and case studies are very approachable, even for those without legal experience. The best part of the class is that you are really pushed into critically thinking about these legal scenarios. Prof. Lenski also keeps the case studies fun and modern, which helps make things amusing. I definitely laughed (quietly) reading one of the prompts during the final.
great, great course if interested in law or classics
Yes, but only if you're prepared to essentially memorize a law textbook. The readings are dense and the case studies require considerable effort to actually master and understand.

Yes! Absolutely yes! It's a lot of work and a lot of reading, but it's nothing like any other history class I've taken here. As a senior history major I'd say this is the hidden gem of the history department. It's nothing like "normal Roman history," although you do learn about Rome's history a lot; it's really like a rigorous law school class but as if you're living in Rome. Please don't miss out on this class!!
Yes!! The stuff we leaned was super interesting and the applications to the modern world were cool
Amazing course! Really recommend

Yes! If you're interested in getting a very detailed overview of Roman law and if you don't mind memorizing things, then you'll get a lot out of this class! It helped me see modern legal practices in an entirely new light.
Maybe. It grew very academic (I understand the irony in that statement) but at times had really interesting windows into history

Absolutely! Especially if you are a History/Poli Sci/Global/EPE/Philosophy major and want to know more about ancient systems of governance. Roman law is super relevant to a lot of modern legal systems, and especially the international legal system used by the Hague. I would also recommend it  for anyone planning on law school since the case studies and exams give you practice in memorizing points of law, applying them, and defending them. Overall great class with really engaging content.
Absolutely!
Yes, because it really gave me a new perspective on the evolution of law.
I would, its a great and interesting look at an area of history I didnt have any experience in, and I feel like I took a lot away from the course.
Yes, the cases studies were a lot of fun and a good way to learn
Not particularly. It was mostly memorization and included repetitive jargon.
If they are willing to put in a lot of work memorizing tiny details
